Internet search found graduation programs in Rwanda: Perplexity search result: Rwanda has adopted a multi-component 'graduation approach' to social protection, formalized in the National Strategy for Sustainable Graduation and supported by BRAC, World Bank, and others[1][2][3][6][9]. The Vision Umurenge Program (VUP) is Rwandaâ€™s flagship poverty program, designed to facilitate sustainable graduation from poverty, combining cash transfers (direct support for households without labor, and public works cash-for-work)[5][3] and provision of productive assets (e.g., One Cow per Family/Girinka, which delivers livestock as household productive assets)[3][2]. The national strategy's pillars require both income support (cash) and productive asset transfers for graduation. Complementary interventions, such as skills training and access to financial services, are also included[1][3][7]. These components are explicitly referenced as core to sustainable graduation in official policy documents[2][3]. Direct Financial Support is a cash component, while Girinka is an asset component.
